image.altText: A skier goes past a snow gun

props.synopsis: Many of the world's ski field operators now rely on snow machines to guarantee business, but others say the practice uses too much water and risks environmental harm.

title.children: Snow guns prove Ben Lomond ski field 'very viable' as park considers future

image.altText: A colourised photo of a Tasmanian tiger.

props.synopsis: Even after a long life, Peggie Bassett can still remember the guttural growl and striking scent of the last known thylacine as it prowled its concrete enclosure.

title.children: Peggie saw a thylacine as a child. She wouldn't ever want to 'go back and see it'

image.altText: A solar system installer adjusts solar panels on the roof of a house.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's energy saver loan scheme gave households and small businesses a chance to obtain interest-free finance for rooftop solar and other energy efficiency measures. It's been so successful, the government decided to end it.

title.children: Scheme to winter-proof houses too successful for its own good

props.synopsis: People were playing in the snow in southern Tasmania, with it settling as low as 150 metres in some spots, but warmer conditions are on the way. The weekend will bring more spring-typical weather for Father's Day.

title.children: Snow drops to 150m in chilly first week of spring in Tasmania

image.altText: An image of a potato cut in half with rust coloured arcs inside on its flesh.

props.synopsis: Victoria, New South Wales and South Australia have placed restrictions on the importation of unprocessed Tasmanian potatoes, following the island state's outbreak of mop-top virus.

title.children: Ban on potato exports from Tasmania to Vic, NSW, SA over mop-top virus

image.altText: man looks neutrally at camera

props.synopsis: There are calls to expand the eligibility of a workplace justice program that allows visa holders to extend their stay while they are pursuing workplace exploitations claims.

title.children: Wages going unpaid as visa workers try to keep their 'head down'

image.altText: A sad child sits in a chair with their face hidden behind their hair

props.synopsis: There can be a range of clues parents can pick up on when their child is being bullied. Here's how to approach it with your child, and how to advocate for them at school.

title.children: What if your child is being bullied, but the school won't act?

image.altText: A small pile of sand and rubbish, including microplastics.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's east coast town of Coles Bay was the first in Australia to ban single-use plastic bags in 2003. How did we go from nation leader to lagger? Airlie Ward talks with reporter Meg Whitfield.

title.children: TassieCast: Why are we yet to ban single-use plastics?

props.synopsis: Labor's Ella Haddad tells ABC Stateline Tasmania integrity is wanting under the Liberal state government.

title.children: Integrity system broken under Liberals, says Haddad

image.altText: Two women and a young boy sitting in a stadium, surrounded by other people.

props.synopsis: Buckingham Palace announces Katharine, Duchess of Kent — who once had a secret job as a primary school music teacher — died on Thursday evening.

title.children: Oldest member of British royal family, who once had secret job, dead at 92

image.altText: Chalmers gestures while sitting at a table.

props.synopsis: This week in Canberra the government seemed to be getting cold feet on its superannuation tax plan and the Coalition reckoned Labor was being less than transparent.

title.children: Is Labor getting cold feet on its superannuation tax plan?

image.altText: A graphic shows Matt Wright against a green background, with chopper motifs behind him.

props.synopsis: The trial of celebrity crocodile wrangler Matt Wright unearthed a culture of helicopter maintenance and safety breaches by his company, which some say have been ongoing in Australia's north for decades.

title.children: Cowboy helicopter culture exposed by Matt Wright trial

image.altText: Kathleen Folbigg and Tracy Chapman.

props.synopsis: Freed after 20 years by medical experts and legal scholars, Kathleen Folbigg's biggest advocate is a friend who has been there through it all.

title.children: After 20 years in jail, Kathleen Folbigg can finally 'greet the day'

image.altText: A brunette woman wearing sunglasses gets out of a car

props.synopsis: Britain's Labour government is enduring a disastrous start to its second year in power, with several snap changes to senior positions on Friday.

title.children: UK deputy PM quits over tax error, sparking major government reshuffle

image.altText: Antonio Guterres speaks in front of the PNG flag.

props.synopsis: United Nations chief António Guterres has refused to respond to comments telling him to "cut the crap" after a national newspaper criticised him for not calling out corruption in Papua New Guinea.

title.children: UN chief walks out on question over calls to 'cut the crap' on PNG visit

image.altText: A family at the kitchen table crowd around a birthday cake for a one year old in a vintage film photo.

props.synopsis: Some memories fade away, while others stay with us for life. But why can we remember some things and not others? And can you "make" a memory? This is what the experts say.

title.children: Do core memories really exist? We asked the experts

image.altText: A man wearing a yellow and green shirt and skull cap looks at the camera, while people waive Australian flags behind him

props.synopsis: Protesters gathered outside the Australian embassy in Tel Aviv, voicing their frustrations over the government's decision to recognise a Palestinian state.

title.children: Australians protest against Palestinian state recognition in Israel

image.altText: A smiling, middle-aged man smiles while he takes a selfie with a girl, whose face is blurred.

props.synopsis: When Andrew Burow went missing from his Brisbane unit, it sparked an investigation full of twists and turns.

title.children: What we know about the mysterious disappearance of Andrew Burow

image.altText: two people walk along the Kerferd Road Pier, Albert Park

props.synopsis: The infamous variability of spring weather across southern Australia will be on full display during the coming week.

title.children: Spring heat, storms and rain headed to south-east Australia

image.altText: A bay with a swirl of dark blue and turquoise blue waters and patches of reef.

props.synopsis: Palau's corals have emerged unscathed from the world's devastating marine heatwaves. Researchers are breeding and planting them to save reefs from disappearing.

title.children: Can Palau's 'lucky reefs' save our oceans?

image.altText: A composite image showing a chicken parmigiana, Cardi B and Reece Walsh

props.synopsis: This week's quiz features Reece Walsh, memories of an extinction, and a pub running out of _____.

title.children: ABC Quote Quiz: Reece Walsh's recovery hack, a beloved character's demise, a pub caught short

image.altText: Man wearing hat and smiling, looking at camera, with green pastures behind him

props.synopsis: The weather bureau forecasts above-average rainfall across the east coast in coming months, which is good for some farmers and challenging for others.

title.children: Bumper grain crop likely as 'unusually high' spring rain forecast

image.altText: A man with spiky hair holds a cocktail and smiles at the camera

props.synopsis: Researchers say one in 50 young people aged 18 to 40 have genetic variants that put them at risk of developing cancer or heart problems.

title.children: Advocates call for more genetic screening for disease risks

image.altText: Alan Joyce smiles on stage

props.synopsis: The national carrier's annual report shows Alan Joyce will pick up his final bonus — a stash of shares worth millions — on Friday's market.

title.children: Alan Joyce collects final $3.8m bonus from Qantas

image.altText: The silhouette of a person holding a football.

props.synopsis: As football teams across Victoria gear up for finals season, a different kind of preparation is underway in the state's domestic violence support services.

title.children: Domestic violence support services brace for football finals spike

image.altText: Penny Wong sits at a table alongside other officials, talking in a microphone to someone across the table.

props.synopsis: Australia is responding to China's display of military power by building closer ties with partners like Japan and racing to "modernise and build our defence force", Richard Marles says, as Penny Wong cautions Daniel Andrews over his decision to attend.

title.children: Australia racing to 'modernise' defence force after show from China: Marles

image.altText: A man clasps his hands in a gesture of thanks while getting into a black car which is surrounded by people and cameras

props.synopsis: Anutin Charnvirakul's elevation to the top job ends a week of political deadlock and ousts a Thai political powerhouse in the process.

title.children: Conservative MP who legalised cannabis Thailand's new PM

image.altText: A young woman and an androgynous-looking person touching hands during a theatre rehearsal in a warehouse space.

props.synopsis: Nearly 100 years since it was written, a team of young theatre-makers re-imagine Virginia Woolf's gender-bending classic, Orlando.

title.children: A time-travelling, gender-bending classic brought to life on rollerskates

image.altText: A man in a black suit gestures and talks

props.synopsis: Democrats and Republicans have grilled US Secretary of Health Robert F Kennedy Jr on his recent vaccine policies.

title.children: 'Denying people vaccines': Senators grill RFK Jr on vaccine policies

image.altText: A soccer player in yellow celebrates a goal in front of two players in white

props.synopsis: Central midfielder Max Balard scores two minutes into his international debut as the Socceroos defeat New Zealand 1-0 in the first leg of the Soccer Ashes in Canberra.

title.children: Debut goal earns disjointed Socceroos victory over New Zealand

image.altText: Ollie Dempsey celebrates a goal with his teammates

props.synopsis: Geelong records a resounding 38-point win over reigning premiers Brisbane to book its spot in the preliminary finals after a pair of controversial umpiring calls in the first half.

title.children: Cats beat Lions to reach prelim despite 'disgraceful' off-ball free kicks

image.altText: A man wearing a dark shirt stands outside a courthouse

props.synopsis: Thomas Sewell will remain behind bars until he faces court on charges related to an attack on Camp Sovereignty over the weekend.

title.children: Neo-Nazi leader denied bail over Camp Sovereignty attack

image.altText: A man in his 30s is speaking while holding a mic

props.synopsis: Gary Stevenson achieved his childhood dream of becoming rich by his mid-20s. The 39-year-old now spends most of his time campaigning against the wealthy.

title.children: The rich are 'squeezing out' ordinary people and this millionaire aims to stop it

image.altText: A cartoon character screenshot from the video game hollow knight silksong

props.synopsis: After years of silence, Team Cherry has released their sequel to one of the most successful Australian-made games of all time, which is expected to break records.

title.children: Australian-made Hollow Knight: Silksong crashes global stores on launch
